params.text:
SECTION 01

Ask an Interesting Question
Supervised Learning - Chemistry

Machine learning algorithms can indeed function as a magic box that can perform the task without any theoretical rules. However, they can do much better if they are built with the domain knowledge in mind.
Introduction: Prediction of Wine Density from Other Physiochemical Properties

• The goal of this notebook is to help you understand the fundamental idea of the process to develop Quantitative Property-Property Relation (QPPR) prediction models.
  • In this small research project, we will build a model that can predict the density of an unknown wine using other properties like acidity or alcohol content.

This notebook is based on the following article tutorial:

L. Deborah et al. “A Gentle Introduction to Machine Learning for Chemists: An Undergraduate Workshop Using Python Notebooks for Visualization, Data Processing, Analysis, and Modeling.” Journal of Chemical Education 98, no. 9 (September 14, 2021): 2892–98. https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.jchemed.1c00142.
Reading 1: QPPR (Quantitative Property-Property Relationship)

Although we are using a simple example, it illustrates an important class of questions in chemistry named QPPR (Quantitative Property-Property Relation). In a QPPR problem, relations between the chemical properties of a given substance need to be identified, which can be used to predict an unmeasured property through other properties. QPPR can achieve the following goals:

1. Lower Experiment Cost: we can first measure the properties that are cheaper to measure and use them to measure those that are more difficult, if not impossible, to measure.

2. Gain Chemical Insights: QPPR models may help us understand hidden relationships between seemingly unrelated properties.

3. Green Chemistry: some properties are easy and cheap to measure, but the measurement process can be harmful to the environment. QPPR may skip this process with just a few Watts of electricity.

In our wine example, we will seek to predict the density of a given wine from other properties, including chloride content, sulfide content, alcohol content, and many more.
Questions 1: QPPR

choices.question: What does QPPR stand for (in the context of this exercise)?
answers:
Quantitative Property Property Relationship

Quality, Productivity, Process, Reliability

Quantum Particle Probability Redistribution

Quick Prototyping and Product Refinement

choices.question: Which of the following is the most difficult to be achieved through QPPR?
answers:
Prediction of Novel Properties

Green Chemistry

Low Experimental Cost

Gain Chemical Insights

overallFeedback.feedback: Not bad.. but you can do better.

l10n.a11yShowSolution: Show the solution. The task will be marked with its correct solution.
l10n.a11yRetry: Retry the task. Reset all responses and start the task over again.

params.text:
SECTION 02

Get the Data & Explore
Supervised Learning - Chemistry

Now that we have an interesting question to investigate, we will now search for the data to learn from. In this chapter, you will learn how to import data from an external source to Orange and to explore them to design your next steps.
Reading 2: the UC Irvine ML Repository

For this example, we will use the data from the ChEMBL database.

We will collect our data from the UC Irvine Machine Learning Repository, which is a popular database in the machine learning community. If interested, you can visit their database and explore their collection: https://archive.ics.uci.edu/

At the point of writing, more than 600 datasets including various numeric and image data are stored in the repository, which serve as great 'model datasets' (just like how mice and fruit flies are great model organisms) to test a machine learning model.

Instructions 01:

Select “File” widget from “Data” tab and add it to the canvas.

Activity 2-1: Importing the Data

In this acitivity, we will download our wine data from the UC Irvine ML repository.

Instructions 02:

Double click on the ‘File’ widget to open its settings. Copy the following URL to the Source and Orange will import the file from the website: https://archive.ics.uci.edu/ml/machine-learning-databases/wine-quality/winequality-white.csv

Instructions 03:

By clicking on the data icon with the number ‘4898’ on the bottom-left corner, you can open a new window where you can explore the data in detail. Take a moment to observe how the data look like.

SECTION 03

Explore the Data
Supervised Learning - Biology

There are a lot of features in the data that we just downloaded to Orange. Which features of wine can we use to predict its density? We will first use a statistical measure called 'correlation' to see which features are most 'correlated' to wine density.
Reading 3: Correlation

Correlation is a statistical measure that tells us how two sets of data are related to each other. Imagine you have two sets of numbers, like the amount of studying you do and your test scores. Correlation helps us see if there's a connection between them.

If they have a positive correlation, it means that as one set of numbers goes up, the other tends to go up too. For example, if you study more, your test scores might also go up.

If they have a negative correlation, it means that as one set of numbers goes up, the other tends to go down. For instance, if you spend more time watching TV, your test scores might decrease.

And if there's no correlation, it means there's no clear relationship between the two sets of data. So correlation helps us understand how changes in one thing might relate to changes in another thing.
Questions 3: Correlation

choices.question: What does a correlation coefficient of -0.9 between two variables indicate?
answers:
There is a strong negative relationship between the variables.

There is a weak negative relationship between the variables.

There is a strong positive relationship between the variables.

There is no relationship between the variables.

choices.question: Which statistical measure assesses the strength and direction of the linear relationship between two variables?
What statistical method is used to determine how closely two sets of data are related to each other?

overallFeedback.feedback: Not bad.. but you can do better.

l10n.a11yShowSolution: Show the solution. The task will be marked with its correct solution.
l10n.a11yRetry: Retry the task. Reset all responses and start the task over again.

params.text:
Instructions 01:

Now we will calculate the correlations between each feature with ‘Correlations’ widget from ‘Unsupervised’ tab. Drag from the ‘File’ widget to the ‘Correlation’ widget to send the data to our new widget.

Activity 3: Exploring Correlations

In this acitivity, we will calculate the correlation between density and each of the other vectors and use the one with the strongest correlation to predict the density.

Instructions 02:

Double click on the added File widget to explore the data. Cotemplate on what each column may mean.

Instructions 03:

As our goal is to predict ‘density’ with other features, we will choose ‘density’ instead of ‘All combinations’.

Instructions 04:

Now we will use ‘Scatter Plot’ from ‘Visualize’ tab to better observe the correlation between density and other features. Drag from the ‘Correlations’ widget to the ‘Scatter Plot’ widget to link the new widget to the workflow.

Instructions 05:

By double clicking on the link between the ‘Correlations’ widget and the ‘Scatter Plot’ widget, you can specify which information to be transferred to the ‘Scatter Plot’ widget. Here, we will simply send the original data.

Instructions 06:

From the correlations widget, we could see that density has the strongest correlation to ‘residual sugar.’ Select density for X-axis and residual sugar for ‘Y-axis’ to observe this correlation on a 2-D plot, where you can see most data points are aligned at a linear fashion.

SECTION 04

Model the Data
Supervised Learning - Biology

We have figured out that residual sugar is the most strongly correlated to density. We will first use 'single regression' to use residual sugar for prediction and then explore 'multiple regression' where other values will also be used for prediction.
Reading 4: Regression

Regression analysis is a statistical method used to understand the relationship between one dependent variable and one or more independent variables.

In single regression, we're looking at the relationship between one dependent variable and one independent variable. For example, if we're trying to predict someone's weight (dependent variable) based on their height (independent variable), we'd use single regression. It helps us understand how changes in one variable (height) might affect changes in another variable (weight).
Questions 4: Regression

choices.question: Which statistical method is used to predict one variable based on the values of another variable (or variables)?
Which statistical technique is used to predict a dependent variable based on one independent variable in a simple model?
answers:
Single regression analysis

Correlation analysis

Multiple regression analysis

Variance analysis

overallFeedback.feedback: Not bad.. but you can do better.

l10n.a11yRetry: Retry the task. Reset all responses and start the task over again.

params.text:
Instructions 01:

Now that we have seen how strong the correlation between ‘residual sugar’ and ‘density’ is, we will use ‘residual sugar’ to predict the density of wine. Add Select Columns widget from Transform tab and link it to the dataset.

Activity 4-1: Single Regression

In this acitivity, we will create a regression model to predict density from residual sugar.

Instructions 02:

Double clicking on the ‘Select Columns’ widget will open up a new window where you can select the target feature to be predicted and also the features to be ignored. We will ignore all the features other than residual sugar and set density as the target.

Instructions 03:

Next, we will add ‘Data Sampler’ widget from ‘Transform’ tab and add it to the workflow. This widget will randomly split the data into ‘test’ and ‘train’ datasets, where train data is used to train the model and test data is used to test the model.

Instructions 04:

Double click on the ‘Data Sampler’ to open up a window where you can further fine-tune the splitting process. For now, we will the default setting as it is.

Instructions 05:

Add the ‘Regression’ widget from the ‘Model’ tab. Link it to the Data Samplers widget.

Instructions 06:

Add the Prediction widget from Evaluate tab. Link it to both linear regression widget and data sampler widget. Check that the linear regression widget passes 'Predictions' and the data sampler widget 'Data' to the predictions widget.

Instructions 07:

Then add a scatter plot widget from visualize tab and link it to the predictions widget.

Instructions 08:

Similar to the scatter plot that we obtained in the previous chapter, we can see that most of the data aligns quite well to the regression line.
Reading 4-2: Multiple Regression

Multiple regression expands on this concept by considering more than one independent variable to predict a single dependent variable. For instance, if we want to predict someone's income (dependent variable), we might consider their education level, years of experience, and age (independent variables). Multiple regression allows us to understand how these multiple factors together influence the outcome.

Instructions 09:

Add a 'Select Columns' widget and link it to the dataset.

Instructions 10:

Double click on the widget to open a new window. This time, not only residual sugar will be added to the features, but all of them will be used for prediction. Place 'density' in the target and everything else in features.

Instructions 11:

Next, we will add ‘Data Sampler’ widget from ‘Transform’ tab and add it to the workflow. This widget will randomly split the data into ‘test’ and ‘train’ datasets, where train data is used to train the model and test data is used to test the model.

Instructions 12:

Just like in single regression, add a linear regression widget from model tab and link it to the data sampler. We can use the same widget because single regression is in fact, a special case of multiple regression.

Instructions 13:

Now add a prediction widget from evaluate tab. Link it to the regression widget and the data sampler widget. It will use the model on the test data and tell you how good the predictions are.

Instructions 14:

We will, as you might have expected, use scatter plot to visualize the prediction results. Add a scatter plot widget and link it to the prediction widget.

Instructions 15:

Double click on the scatter plot widget to see the results. Note that individual data points may be different from yours to the example as the data sampler widget selects test data randomly. If you do not see the regression line, make sure you check on the 'Show regression line' checkbox.

Is the prediction better than single regression?

SECTION 05

Communicate the Results
Supervised Learning - Biology

Congratulations on building your Regression model! We could see that the predictions were indeed acceptable through scatter plots, but how good are these predictions? To communicate the performance of your model, we need to know the metrics to evalute the model.
Reading 5: Evaluation Metrics

Here are some metrics that Orange supports to evalute a model.

Accuracy: Of all the predictions we made, how many were correct?

Precision: Of all the positive predictions we made, how many were correct?

Recall: Of all the predictions that should have been positive, how many did we got correct?

f1-score: A score that combines precision and recall that is 1 for a perfect model and 0 for a terrible model.

MCC: Stands for Mathew's Correlation Coefficient, also called Phi coefficient. Another combined score that is also 1 for a perfect model and 0 for a terrible model.

Instructions 01:

Double clicking on the “Predictions” widget will open up the report window. You can see what the model predicted for each individual wine from test data and also how ‘sure’ the model was with each prediction.

At the bottom of the window there are several evaluation metrics to show how good the prediction was overall

Activity 5: Evaluating the Model

After making predictions, we can use them to evaluate our model. Orange gives such information directly from the "Predictions" widget.
Questions 5: Evaluating the Model

choices.question: Which of the following best fits the description? Of all the predictions we made, how many were correct?
Which of the following best fits the description? Of all the positive predictions we made, how many were correct?
Which of the following best fits the description? Of all the predictions that should have been positive, how many did we got correct?
Which of the following best fits the description? A score that combines precision and recall that is 1 for a perfect model and 0 for a terrible model.
Which of the following is the closest to the Precision of our model?

overallFeedback.feedback: Not bad.. but you can do better.
